isis.stitle: BRAKE COMPONENTS: This Service Manual Section should be used for reference only. For more current service information on all components go to the Bendix website from the ISIS Suppliers menu and refer to the Service Data Sheets. - AIR DRYER - CYCLO-GARD

svcsubproc.title: Description
svcsubproc.para: The Cyclo-Gard air dryer is a heat transfer type air dryer that cools compressed air pumped from the compressor to ambient temperature before it enters the supply reservoir. It is also designed to prevent water, oil, carbon and sludge from entering the braking system air supply.
A thermostatically controlled heater is provided to keep moisture from freezing inside the dryer or drain valve during cold weather operation.
A check valve is provided in the discharge port of the dryer to permit depressurizing the dryer without draining the air system.

svcsubproc.title: Operation

figure.caption: Figure 83. Cyclo-Gard Air Dryer - Air Flow

svcsubproc.para: Hot air from the compressor enters the dryer at the inlet and is diverted at a right angle around the sump ( Figure 83 ), creating a spinning action. Centrifugal force removes oil and other contaminants.

Air leaves the sump through the exit tube and is directed by the baffle to flow against the tube wall. The heat of compression is dissipated through the tube and the cooling fins, and the air temperature drops rapidly from as high as 500 degrees F to about 10 degrees above ambient temperature.
Condensed moisture runs down the tube wall and settles at the bottom of the dryer.

The cooled air then passes through a wire mesh filter which collects any minute droplets of moisture that may remain. Clean, dry air then leaves the dryer through the check valve to the supply reservoir.

figure.caption: Figure 84. Cyclo-Gard Air Dryer - Unload Cycle

svcsubproc.para: When system air pressure builds to governed pressure, the air compressor governor will unload the compressor and, at the same time, the governor directs system air pressure to the air dryer unloading valve which causes the valve to open. When the unloading valve opens, the check valve in the dryer discharge port will close, and air in the dryer will escape out the unloader valve ( Figure 84 ). Moisture and other contaminants will be carried out the exhaust port of the unloader valve by the escaping air.

svcsubproc.title: Maintenance
svcsubproc.para:
The dryer should be inspected and cleaned every 200,000 miles. Wipe out the inside and check for any damage to the baffle or other parts. Remove the mesh filter and soak in solvent to remove accumulated oil. Refer to
DISASSEMBLE - AIR DRYER
for the procedure to remove the filter from the air dryer.

note.para: Be sure the filter is completely dry before it is reinstalled in the dryer.

svcsubproc.para: The only moving parts in the air dryer are the check valve and the unloader valve. No maintenance is required other than the 200,000 mile cleaning as long as the unloader valve and check valve operate properly when the compressor is running in the unload cycle.

svcsubproc.title: Service Checks
svcsubproc.para: The heater keeps the sump from freezing in cold weather operation. The heater will automatically turn ON when the thermostatic temperature falls below 35 degrees F and automatically turn OFF when the thermostatic temperature rises above 75 degrees F. To test the heater, disconnect the unit and place it in a cup of ice water for five minutes. Reconnect the heater. The heater should heat up and continue heating until the thermostat reaches 75 degrees F. At 75 degrees F, the heater should turn itself OFF. A heater unit that fails to perform as described above should be replaced.
With the engine running, pump the brakes until the compressor cuts in (starts pumping). Verify that the unloader valve discharge port does not leak any air while the compressor is cut in (pumping).

When the compressor cuts out (stops pumping), listen for a 2 second high pressure discharge at the unloader valve discharge port. This is normal. The unloader valve will remain in the open position until the compressor cuts in again.

If the unloader valve leaks air while the compressor is cut in, or does not open (discharge air) when the compressor cuts out, then the valve is not working properly. A non-functioning valve should be cleaned, rebuilt or replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 85. Cyclo-Gard Air Dryer - Unloader Valve Test

svcsubproc.para: Turn the engine off and perform the following test. It is not necessary to remove the unloader valve for this test.

step1.para: Drain all air from the air system.

warning.para: Do not attempt to remove any component from the air dryer or disassemble any component on the air dryer while the air system is under pressure. High pressure air can cause personal injury or death.

step1.para: Disconnect the sensing line from the air compressor to the unloader valve and drain any water in the line.

Loosen the unloader valve lock nut and unscrew the cap from the body and dry out any water in the cap. Remove the piston. Clean and relube the piston with low temperature grease (DOW 55 or equivalent) before reinstalling.

Push the washer (Item 5, Figure 85 ) into the plunger body with your thumb. It should depress with very little effort. Travel should be approximately 1/4 inch and the washer should return flush with the end of the body when released. If the plunger does not function as described above, remove the valve and disassemble the plunger. Determine the reason for the failure and repair the assembly. Unloader valve repair kits are available from your Parts Department.
If the plunger travel is normal, reassemble the valve with the open side of the piston toward the plunger washer ( Figure 85 ). Tighten cap fully onto the body. Tighten lock nut.

warning.para: Do not attempt to remove the air dryer or any component from the air dryer while the air system is under pressure. High pressure air can cause personal injury or death.

step1.para: Block wheels of the vehicle.
Drain all air from the air system.
Disconnect the compressor discharge and sensor lines at the dryer.
Disconnect the discharge line at the check valve.
Unplug the heater electrical connector from the heater on the dryer.
Remove the dryer mounting bolts and remove the dryer from the vehicle.

warning.para: Do not attempt to remove the air dryer or any component from the air dryer while the air system is under pressure. High pressure air can cause personal injury or death.

step1.para: Block wheels of the vehicle.
Drain all air from the air system.
Disconnect the sensor line from the compressor at the unloader valve.

warning.para: Do not attempt to remove the air dryer or any component from the air dryer while the air system is under pressure. High pressure air can cause personal injury or death.

step1.para: Block wheels of the vehicle.
Drain all air from the air system.
Disconnect the air dryer discharge line from the check valve.
Unthread the check valve from the dryer.
Unplug the heater electrical connector.
Unthread the heater from the base of the dryer.
Remove the bolt that secures the bottom of the dryer mounting bracket to the dryer.

Remove the two bolts that secure the mounting bracket to the top head ( Figure 86 ). Mark the two bolts that secure the dryer mounting bracket to the top head to insure they are reinstalled in the same location.

Remove the remaining six bolts that secure the top head to the body assembly ( Figure 86 ). Care should be taken while removing these bolts. The components held inside the dryer by these bolts are under spring tension.
Carefully lift the top head off the dryer and remove the upper filter spring, upper strainer plate, filter material, lower strainer plate, lower filter spring, baffle, exit tube and gasket.
Remove the support ring from inside the dryer cavity.
Unthread the unloader valve, heater and emergency plug assembly from the base of the dryer.

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble - Unloader Valve
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 85 for all item numbers in parentheses.

step1.para: Loosen the lock nut (Item 7) and unscrew the cap (Item 1) from the valve body.
Remove the piston (Item 2) from the valve body.
Remove the O-ring (Item 3) from the piston.
On the piston end of the plunger assembly, remove the snap ring (Item 4) on the outside of the washer (Item 5).
Lightly tap the washer end of the plunger assembly against the palm of your hand to remove the washer (Item 5).
Remove the inner snap ring (Item 4).
Remove the spring (Item 6).
Push the plunger (Item 8) out the opposite end of the housing from the washer end.
Remove the quad ring (Item 9) from the plunger.
Wipe out the inside of the air dryer housing and check for damage to the baffle.
If the baffle is damaged, if must be replaced to insure proper cooling of the air.
Soak the mesh filter in solvent to remove accumulated oil.

note.para: The filter must be completely dry before it is reinstalled in the dryer.

step1.para: Wipe the piston, washer, plunger and inside of the unloader valve body clean. Check for wear. If the piston and/or bore of the plunger body are damaged or worn, the complete valve must be replaced.

svcsubproc.title: Assemble - Unloader Valve
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 85 for all items in parentheses.

step1.para: As each part is installed, lubricate with low temperature grease (DOW 55 or equal).
Install new quad ring (Item 9) on the plunger (Item 8).
Install the plunger into the plunger body (Item 10) so the quad ring end of the plunger is on the pipe nipple end of the plunger body.
From the washer end, install a new spring (Item 6).
Install a new snap ring (Item 4) on the inner groove of the plunger shaft.
Install a new washer (Item 5).
Install a new snap ring (Item 4) on the plunger shaft to hold the washer in place.

Push the washer (Item 5) into the plunger body with your thumb. It should depress with very little effort. Travel should be approximately 1/4 inch and the washer should return flush with the end of the body when released. If the plunger does not function as described above, disassemble the plunger assembly, determine the reason for the failure and repair the assembly.
Install a new O-ring (Item 3) on the piston (Item 2).
Install the piston (Item 2) with the open end toward the washer (Item 5) in the plunger body (Item 10).
Install and tighten the cap (Item 1) fully onto the plunger body. Tighten the lock nut (Item 7) to hold the cap in place.

svcsubproc.title: Assemble - Air Dryer
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 86 for all items referenced in the following text.

step1.para: Install a new gasket on the upper flange of the body assembly. The gasket is installed by the manufacturer without a sealer.
Install the support ring in the dryer housing cavity so that it rest completely on the indentations inside the lower end of the cavity.
Install the exit tube so it rests completely on the support ring.
Install the baffle.
Install lower filter spring, lower strainer plate, filter material, upper strainer plate and upper filter spring in this order.
Position the top head over the assembly so the upper filter spring is centered on the bottom side of the top head.

Push the top head down (against the spring tension) so it rests against the gasket. Install two top head bolts (not the bolts that secure the hanger bracket to the assembly). Tighten finger tight. Install the remaining bolts and the mounting bracket. Use the bolts that were marked during disassembly to hold the mounting bracket in place. Tighten all bolts to 25 to 30 ft-lbs. (34 to 41 N· m).
Install the bolt that secures the bottom of the hanger bracket to the dryer. Tighten to 25 to 30 ft-lbs. (34 to 41 N· m).
Install the unloader valve, check valve, heater and emergency plug assembly.
Mount the air dryer assembly to the vehicle. Tighten all mounting bolts to 30 to 38 ft-lbs. (41 to 51 N· m).
Connect and tighten the governor sensing line to the unloader valve, the compressor discharge line to the air dryer and the air dryer discharge line to the check valve.
Connect the electrical connector to the heater.
Build air pressure in the system and check the air dryer and all fittings for air leaks. Repair as required.
The discharge cycle should last for only a few seconds. A faulty check valve will allow a longer discharge period and cause constant cycling, probably from 30 to 50 seconds apart.

The unloader valve should open only when pressure is applied from the governor during the governor unload cycle. If the valve stays open during the pumping cycle, the air system cannot be brought up to operating pressure since air intended for the system will be escaping through the unloader valve exhaust port. To determine the source of the condition, disconnect the air line at the unloader valve cap. If the valve does not close, it should be repaired or replaced. If it does close, it is functioning properly and the governor may be faulty.

If there is no blow down when the compressor is in the unload cycle, the unloader valve should be repaired or replaced as soon as possible. Continued operation over a period of time can allow the water level to build up in the sump of the unit. If the water level reaches a point higher than the inlet port, the air pressure can lift the water with sufficient force to damage the baffle. A damaged baffle will not allow the unit to cool the air flow and will result in high moisture content in the reservoirs.
